knowledge_graph.title: Climate change
knowledge_graph.description: Present-day climate change includes both global warming—the ongoing increase in global average temperature—and its wider effects on Earth's climate system. Climate change in a broader sense also includes previous long-term changes to Earth's climate.

list: The Earth just keeps getting hotter.
Greenhouse gas levels are higher than ever.
Extreme weather is getting more extreme.
Biodiversity loss is at an all-time high.

related_questions.question: What are the 10 major effects of climate change?

text_blocks.snippet: Ten key effects of climate change include hotter temperatures and more frequent heatwaves, increased intensity and frequency of extreme weather events like storms and heavy rainfall, rising sea levels due to melting ice, more severe and prolonged droughts, more frequent and devastating wildfires, ocean warming and acidification, shrinking polar ice and glaciers, loss of biodiversity as species struggle to adapt, impacts on food security from changing growing conditions, and increased human health risks from smog, waterborne diseases, and heat-related illnesses.
snippet_highlighted_words: hotter temperatures and more frequent heatwaves, increased intensity and frequency of extreme weather events like storms and heavy rainfall, rising sea levels due to melting ice, more severe and prolonged droughts, more frequent and devastating wildfires, ocean warming and acidification, shrinking polar ice and glaciers, loss of biodiversity as species struggle to adapt, impacts on food security from changing growing conditions, and increased human health risks from smog, waterborne diseases, and heat-related illnesses

list.title: 1. Rising Global Temperatures:
list.snippet: The global average surface temperature is increasing, leading to more frequent and intense heatwaves.

list.title: 2. Extreme Weather:
list.snippet: Climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, such as heavy rainfall, severe storms, and tropical cyclones.

list.title: 3. Melting Ice and Glaciers:
list.snippet: Ice sheets, glaciers, and sea ice are melting at an accelerated rate, contributing to rising sea levels and altering ecosystems.

list.title: 4. Rising Sea Levels:
list.snippet: The melting of polar ice and glaciers, along with the thermal expansion of warming water, causes sea levels to rise, threatening coastal communities.

list.title: 5. Drought and Water Scarcity:
list.snippet: Changes in rainfall patterns and increased evaporation are leading to more frequent, severe, and prolonged droughts.

list.title: 6. Increased Wildfires:
list.snippet: Hotter temperatures and drier conditions contribute to an increase in the frequency and intensity of wildfires.

list.title: 7. Ocean Warming and Acidification:
list.snippet: The oceans are warming and becoming more acidic due to absorbing excess carbon dioxide, which harms marine life.

list.title: 8. Biodiversity Loss:
list.snippet: Many plant and animal species are struggling to adapt to rapid changes in their habitats, leading to a decline in biodiversity.

list.title: 1. Threats to Food Security:
list.snippet: Changes in weather patterns, increased pests, and crop failures make it harder to grow and access food, particularly for vulnerable populations.

list.title: 2. Health Risks:
list.snippet: Climate change exacerbates health problems such as asthma, heart disease, and heat stroke, while also increasing the risk of waterborne diseases and poor air quality from smog and wildfire smoke.

related_questions.question: How can we fix climate change?

text_blocks.snippet: To fix climate change, we must drastically reduce greenhouse gas emissions by transitioning away from fossil fuels to renewable energy like solar and wind power, improving energy efficiency, and adopting sustainable transportation and practices. Simultaneously, actions such as reforesting and restoring nature, changing agricultural practices, reducing consumption, and implementing carbon capture technologies are necessary to absorb existing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
snippet_highlighted_words: drastically reduce greenhouse gas emissions by transitioning away from fossil fuels to renewable energy like solar and wind power, improving energy efficiency, and adopting sustainable transportation and practices

text_blocks.snippet: Transition to Clean Energy & Reduce Emissions

list.title: Invest in Renewable Energy:
list.snippet: Replace fossil fuels with solar, wind, and other renewable energy sources to power homes and industries.

list.title: Improve Energy Efficiency:
list.snippet: Reduce energy consumption through better home insulation, using energy-efficient appliances, and turning off lights when not needed.

list.title: Adopt Sustainable Transportation:
list.snippet: Walk, bike, use public transport, carpool, and switch to fuel-efficient or electric vehicles to lower emissions from travel.

list.title: Reduce Industrial Emissions:
list.snippet: Update industrial processes to be more energy-efficient and explore carbon capture and storage technologies for unavoidable emissions.

list.title: Reforest and Restore Nature:
list.snippet: Plant trees, restore forests, and protect ecosystems like oceans and seagrasses, which absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.

list.title: Promote Sustainable Agriculture:
list.snippet: Implement farming practices, like using cover crops, that help store more carbon in the soil.

list.title: Eat Less Meat:
list.snippet: Shifting towards more plant-based diets can significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions from livestock.

list.title: Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle:
list.snippet: Minimize waste and reduce overall consumption of goods, as producing and transporting products requires energy.

list.title: Develop Carbon Removal Technologies:
list.snippet: Invest in and deploy technologies like direct air capture to remove existing CO2 from the atmosphere.

list.title: Adapt to Climate Impacts:
list.snippet: Design communities and infrastructure with rising sea levels and other climate changes in mind to build resilience.

text_blocks.snippet: Ultimately, achieving "net zero" emissions by 2050, where no more carbon is added to the atmosphere than is removed, is crucial to limit global warming and avoid the worst impacts of climate change.
